Mr Salmond is the sole shareholder in Chronicles Of Deer, which handles publishing income from hisreferendum diary The Dream Shall Never Die.Read more:Alex Salmond reports Scottish Government to information watchdogHis total known equity was therefore about pound, across the two firms, which between them had about pound, in the bank.The Slainte Media accounts, published at Companies House, cover the period from the firmrsquos creation in July  to November  last year, shortly after his crowdfunder appeal.They state current assets of pound,, including pound, ldquocash at bank and at hand.This was offset by pound, due to unidentied creditors, leaving net current assets of pound,. Fixed assets of pound, and a pound, investment ndash thought to be a % stake in a fledgling IT firm ndash took total assets less current liabilities to pound,.Other accounts filed last year show Chronicles Of Deer had total assets of pound,, including pound, ldquocash in hand and at bank, at February , .The accounts offer no figures on Mr Salmondrsquos potential tax liabilities and it is not knownthere would have been any dficulties in using the assets or bank funds held by the companies to cover legal costs.After taking creditors into accounts, total net assets and share equity were pound,, compared to pound, in  and pound, in .Despite the success of his ventures, Mr Salmond last August asked supporters to help pay for a legal action against the Scottish Government over its handling of disputed sexual misconduct allegations against him ndash it raised pound, in under three days.He later won a judicial review at the Court of Session after showing the Government bungled an in-house investigation into claims made against him in early .Ministers admitted the lead investigating official had been in prior contact with his accusers, rendering the process unlawful, unfair and ldquotainted by apparent bias.A Holyrood committee is now looking into how the process went awry and left taxpayers with a pound, legal bill.After the Chronicles Of Deer figures emerged last year, Mr Salmondrsquos spokesman said all contributed to the crowdfunder knew the objectives and that the sums raised would only be used for the purpose of Judicial Review, with any excess donated to good causes.Separately, Mr Salmond appeared in court in January charged with two counts of attempted rape, nine of sexual assault, two of indecent assault and one of breach of the peace.He strongly denies any criminality.

title: paul-hutcheon-nicola-sturgeons-route-to-indyref2-is-through-jeremy-corbyn
story: NICOLA Sturgeon would do well to learn from the mistakes of David Cameron when planning another independence referendum.Cameron caved in to party hardliners on Brexit when he did not need to, ignoring public opinion which was uninterested in a vote on membership of the European Union.The former PM was motivated by a desire to keep his party together, rather than acting in the national self-interest. He compounded his blunder by holding back on criticising Boris Johnson during the referendum campaign. His legacy is in shreds.Sturgeon stands at a similar crossroads to the one Cameron faced in  when he announced an In Out referendum. Only a very small proportion of voters support an early indyref and opinion polls almost unormly show a majority is against secession. The First Minister is aware that Brexit is an unwelcome complication and realises her time would be better spent on the lsquowhyrsquo of independence, not the lsquowhenrsquo.: SNP members support new currency as soon as practicableEven so, Sturgeon last week informed MSPs that she wanted a second indyref within two years. She also made a concession to her partyrsquos Left by proposing changes to the SNPrsquos economic case - approved yesterday at their conference - to replace the pound with a new currency, a hugely risky move. Like Cameron, she was appeasing her own side.However, senior SNP figures believe the circumstances could exist for a Section  deal. Look at the small print of Sturgeonrsquos statement to MSPs last week. She wants to pass a framework bill - setting out the rules of a possible referendum - before the end of the year. She said the Tory Government ldquomight soon be out of office. She said she would seek agreement on a transfer of power at an ldquoappropriate point.Sturgeon believes Theresa Mayrsquos chaotic Government will fall by the end of the year, to be replaced by a minority Labour administration led by Jeremy Corbyn. Consider the arithmetic. The Tories would block every left-wing reform proposed by Corbyn. The Lib Dems would not have the numbers to prop him up, eventhey wanted to. The Democratic Unionist Party would seethe at the prospect of a Sinn Fein sympathiser like Corbyn being in Downing Street.:Scottish Labour meltdown over leaked European election messagesCorbynrsquos only option - unless a general election gave him an unlikely majority - would be to seek the support of the thirty-plus contingent of SNP MPs for the Budget and other legislation. Sturgeonrsquos party would be the kingmaker. Just as the DUP secured an extra poundbn from May, so too would the Nationalists demand a Section  deal from Corbyn.It is not beyond the realms of possibility to imagine Corbyn agreeing to such a request. In , he said he would allow a second referendumthe ldquoScottish Parliament and the Scottish people want it. Asked last year what he would doSturgeon sought the power to hold another indyref, he replied: "We would obviously decide at the time." Corbyn has political red lines, but maintaining the integrity of the UK does not appear to be one of them.If you look at politics through a Unionist Labour telescope, there is an obvious solution to this looming problem. Scottish Labour, not Corbyn, has been on the front line of the independence debate. It is party activists north of the border, not in London, who have been shouted at and dismissed as ldquored Tories. Scottish Labour is much more hostile to indyref than Corbyn and his allies.Richard Leonard could insist that Scottish Labour sets the policy on an independence referendum for the UK party. If Scottish Labour wanted to unequivocally rule out a Section  order, Corbyn should follow suit. He would also be obliged to stick to this script whenever he ventured to Scotland, rather than go off on one of his many indy rfs. The branch office would call the shots on this one.The alternative is that Parliament could, to borrow an old phrase used by Alex Salmond, be ldquohung by a Scottish rope. In this context, ldquoScottish would mean SNP. Sturgeon may have made tactical mistakes last week, but her party is in line to have a dramatic effect on UK politics.

title: mundell-signals-tories-may-never-agree-to-indyref2-deal
story: Asked by the Herald on Sunday whether he could ldquoever imagine a Tory Government agreeing to transfer this power to MSPs, David Mundell said: ldquoNo, I canrsquot envisage that circumstance.Mundell also said that a Jeremy Corbyn-led Government was Nicola Sturgeonrsquos ldquoonly route to a second referendum.Paul Hutcheon: Nicola Sturgeons route to indyref is through Jeremy CorbynSturgeon last week updated MSPs on her plans for indyref, which involved the introduction of a framework bill to set the rules on a potential referendum. She wants to hold the vote within two years.David Lidington, who is effectively Mayrsquos deputy, responded to the call by ruling out indyref before .Mundellrsquos intervention, which he made in an interview with this newspaper, goes much further than this Cabinet colleague.On Brexit, Mundell also repeated his opposition to a second referendum on the UKrsquos membership of the European Union, but he did offer a view on how he would voteParliament backed this policy.Interview: Scotland Secretary David Mundell on independence, Brexit and David CameronAsked whether he would vote Remain, as he had done in , he replied: ldquoNo. I would find it dficult to vote Remain in a future referendum because it would not be respecting the outcome of the previous referendum.Mundell also stepped up his criticism of Tory leadership frontrunner Boris Johnson. He said: ldquoI donrsquot think that he is someone who does particularly gel in Scotland.He added: ldquoHe has not dipped his toe signicantly into the Scottish political scene. He is not necessarily somebody who has an obvious affinity with Scotland.He also likened some of his colleagues at Westminster to supporters of Scottish independence:ldquoThere are a group of Conservative colleagues whose entire political approach is driven by Brexit.ldquoThey are as obsessive about Brexit as Nicola Sturgeon and some of her colleagues are about independence. title: ian-blackford-scotland-deserves-better-future-than-brexit-britain

title: the-man-who-inspired-mindhunter-and-silence-of-the-lambs
story: AT first glance John E Douglas appears the perfect clean-cut FBI agent - the kind of investigator who comes ready-made from the agencys headquarters at Quantico, Virginia. A sharp pinstripe suit, crisp pocket hankie, pressed white shirt, silk monotone tie. But the clothes are just a front.Douglas spends his le among the most dangerous, predatory offenders - rapists, murderers, serial killers. Men who live behind masks - masks of sanity, masks of Mr Nice Guy until itrsquos too late, real masks put over their faces at night before they kill.The suit and tie that Douglas wears, itrsquos a mask too - it gives him authority when he sits across the prison visiting table from criminals constantly searching for signs of weakness to exploit, one eye ever hunting for a victim.Douglas developed the science - some would say art - of criminal profiling. A profiler takes every shred of evidence from a crime scene and uses it to develop a picture of who the killer is - at times the results can be astounding, pegging with chilling accuracy the age, race, profession, marital status, personality and location of the offender. Douglas looked at the crimes of Jack the Ripper and said with certainty that the murderer - who to this day remains unknown - lived slap-bang in the middle of his killing grounds in the east end of London. Most serial murders start killing close to home - their lsquocomfort zonersquo. As Douglas says: "If you want to understand the artist, look at his art."The method of killing is often revelatory about the killerrsquos personality. If a victim is found strangled from behind, then most likely the killer knew them - few people, even the most psychopathic, would look into the eyes of someone they knew as they died. Multiple wounds to a victimrsquos face and upper body  Then therersquos probably a personal motive. Revenge, perhaps - jealousy.The key to Douglas unlocking the secrets of the criminal mind was a series of interviews he conducted with notorious offenders beginning in the s - some call it the Golden Age of Serial Killing - and continuing to this day. He interviewed the likes of David Berkowitz - the Son of Sam - Charles Manson, Ed Kemper, John Wayne Gacy, Gary Heidnik, Ted Bundy and Richard Speck. Between them, these men alone are responsible for the deaths of nearly  people. Douglasrsquo new book lsquoThe Killer Across the Tablersquo explains how these interviews taught him what makes a killer tick - why killers kill. Little wonder, then, that he was the inspiration for the character of FBI chief Jack Crawford in Silence of the Lambs, and had his career immortalised in the Netflix crime series Mindhunter, about tofor a second season.At the heart of understanding the worst offenders - serial killers, sex murderers, repeat rapists - lie three simple words, says Douglas: lsquoManipulation. Domination. Controlrsquo. These are the prime motivators. But why do those three simple words drive such men  The answer lies somewhere in their childhood for itrsquos there that empathy seems to have been drained from them, and empathy is the one thing which makes us human. Nearly all suffered abuse of one kind or another as children. "They are all predators, " says Douglas, "and all grew up without forming trusting bonds with other human beings during their formative years".Douglasrsquo work has led him inevitably to ask big questions about le, specically lsquoare some people born evil rsquo. When it comes to the nature versus nurture debate, Douglas says: "I would argue that, while no-one who does not have certain inborn tendencies toward impulsivity, anger, and or sadistic perversions is going to evolve into a predator because of bad upbringing, there is no doubt in my mind that those possessing such inborn tendencies can be pushed along the path to predation by negative influences as they grow up and mature."As an example, he points to one of the most notorious serial killers in history - Ed Kemper, the so-called Co-ed Killer who murdered his grandparents when he was , then went on to kill a series of young hitchhikers, and his mother. He stands six foot nine, weighs  pound, and has an IQ of .In order to understand the very essence of Kemperrsquos crimes, Douglas tried to unravel the killerrsquos fantasy le, his lsquoemotional reasonsrsquo for murder. Like many such men, Kemper had a dficult relationship with an emotionally cold mother. None of Kemperrsquos victims were treated sadistically. Unlike many other killers, it wasnrsquot torture or humiliation that motivated him. Kemper told Douglas that he was lsquoevicting them from their bodiesrsquo so he could be with them after death. He was lonely - and like all violent and sexual offenders he was also a narcissist. The same psychopathology crops up again and again in Douglasrsquo work: humiliation or abuse in childhood leaves a young man, with a high sense of his own importance, unfit for the world - incapable of ing in work or a relationship - and this piles on more humiliation to their already fragile sense of self they are raw with anger and sensitive to any slight empathy has been expunged from them. Killing becomes an act which gives them power, control, domination.Serial offenders - paedophiles, rapists, killers - are also serial manipulators of the authorities. Lying isnrsquot just second nature - itrsquos fun. "On one of his court-mandated visits to a state psychiatrist Ed Kemper had the head of his latest victim, a -year-old girl, in the trunk of his car," says Douglas. "During that particular interview, the psychiatrist concluded he was no longer a threat to himself or others and recommended his juvenile record be sealed." Suffice to say, Douglas does not hold to the idea that such offenders can be rehabilitated.However, the deep-seated narcissism and inadequacy of serial offenders also makes them easy to manipulate. In his interviews with criminals, Douglas tries to maintain control of the situation as a figure of authority - hence the FBI suit and tie - while still allowing the killer to feel a sense of power and control. In his first interview with David Berkowitz, Douglas told him that another multiple murder had written to police saying lsquohe wants to be powerful like yoursquo. Berkowitz immediately relaxed and said to Douglas: "What do you want to know "When Douglas interviews assassins - like James Earl Ray who shot Martin Luther King - he sits them lsquofacing the window or door because they tend to be paranoid and will be distractedthey canrsquot psychologically escape when stressed by the interviewrsquo. During an interview with Charles Manson, all of five foot two, "he climbed up onto the back of a chair at the head of the table so he could lord it over us from a superior position, just as he used to sit on top of boulder to preach to his lsquofamilyrsquo of followers".Douglas says his goal in all these interviews is lsquoto turn on the DVDrsquo inside the minds of these men. All serial offenders have rich, though dark, fantasy lives - they vividly replay their crimes in their minds. Douglas takes hours leading offenders through humdrum small talk and le history until they begin speaking freely about the crimes they committed. Thatrsquos when Douglas gets closest to honesty and can really pick apart why a killer killed.That moment can be lsquoalmost like a metamorphosesrsquo, he says. He describes one child killer, Joseph McGowan, transforming before his eyes as he began to talk openly of his crimes. "His physical appearance seemed to change before my eyes," he said. "His eyes were unfocused as he looked beyond me. I could tell he was looking completely inward - back a quarter of a century. I could sense he was clicking back to the one story that had never left his mind."Most lsquoordinaryrsquo people who commit murder donrsquot take pleasure in the act itself - eventhey hate the person theyrsquove killed. However, the sexual or serial murderer does. McGowan took extreme pleasure in killing. "The gratication and emotional fulfilment of the act went through to the brutal murder itself and his ability to destroy something." When Douglas asked McGowan to show the expression that was on his face at the time of the killing, lsquohis face contorted into what I would characterise as an intense, malevolently satisfied grimacersquo.With such killers lsquothe fixation was with the act itself, not the personality or specicity of the victimrsquo. In other words, a killer like McGowan - who was also a social inadequate with a domineering mother - would have killed anyone to satisfy his urge to murder, a child was just an easier victim than an adult woman, or even a man."The only real fantasy here was a fantasy of power," Douglas added. "For a person with criminal tendencies who perceives he has little power or control over his own le, murder embodies the ultimate power."Therersquos one consistent trait among all serial predators, says Douglas, and thatrsquos lsquotwo emotional concepts constantly warring within them. One is a feeling of grandiosity and entitlement. The other is a deep-seated and pervasive sense of inferiority.rsquoEven though their actions may appear insane, serial offenders are not mad. Douglas cites the case of Dennis Rader, the BTK killer - BTK standing for bind, torture, kill - who murdered entire families. When it seemed like his we suspected him of aberrant behaviour, Rader was able to stop killing for years before starting again. "This layoff proved to me Raderrsquos sanity and rationality," says Douglas.Most serial offenders display lsquothe homicidal triadrsquo when young - bed-wetting, fire starting and cruelty to animals. The psychology of the crime scene also points to the psychology of the criminal. Is it organised  In other words, was the crime well planned, is there little evidence left behind, was the getaway effective  Or was it disorganised - meaning the killer might be young, less experienced, maybe under the influence of drink or drugs.Serial offenders are also born to compartmentalise - in a way that no normal person could. John Wayne Gacy had  boys buried under his house, yet he went about his le as a happily married man, active in local politics and successful in his business le. "Predators like these exist on two distinct psychic planes," says Douglas."Serial killers are constantly on the hunt, some of them almost nightly," Douglas adds. "The hunt is a key component of the fantasy and often just as fulfilling as the crime itself."Nearly all such offenders see themselves as wronged by the world, and often blame their acts on some catalyst which set them off - being jilted, losing a job, friends shunning them, a terrible childhood, exposure to pornography, or a even dog barking next door according to the Son of Sam. Often they blame the victim too - their skirt was too short, their door was unlocked, they shouldnrsquot have been out at night. "Nearly all serial killers believe their crimes are justied, or at least explainable," Douglas says. "They perceive themselves as the true victims - yet another manestation of their extreme narcissism".The truth is, says Douglas, these men made a choice to kill. Whether they had a dreadful childhood or not - and many did suffer appalling physical, emotional and sexual abuse - they knew the dference between right and wrong. They were not pre-programmed to kill. The acted of their own freewill. They want to lsquoplay Godrsquo, as Douglas puts it. "The reality is that a bad background is not an excuse for murder."Self-evidently, confronting such horror has its cost. "As an investigator of violent crime, you try to be as emotionally detached as possible, not only to maintain your objectivity and critical judgement, but also to preserve your sanity," he says. "In fact, having to put myself, as a behavioural profiler, into the head of every victim whose case I work has definitely taken its psychic toll on me throughout my career."* The Killer Across the Table: Unlocking the Secrets of Serial Killers and Predators with the FBIrsquos Original Mindhunter by John E Douglas and Mark Olshaker is published by William Collins on May  priced pound in hardback.THE KILLERS ACROSS THE TABLEJOHN Douglas has spent time in the company of some of the most infamous offenders in criminal history. They include:David Berkowitz aka the Son of Sam. Berkowitz went on a murder spree in the New York during the summer of  killing six people. He sent letters to the police signed Mr Monster and when caught claimed a demon inside a dog belonging to his neighbour lsquoSamrsquo instructed him to kill. He remains behind bars.Ted Bundy. The seemingly charming, highly intelligent and attractive Bundy brought terror to America in the s. He was finally caught after two escapes from custody and confessed to  murders. He died in the electric chair in  with crowds outside chanting lsquoBurn, Bundy, Burnrsquo.Richard Speck. He tortured, raped and murdered eight student nurses in . He was condemned to die but the death sentence was overturned. He died in prison after serving  years.Gary Ridgway aka the Green River Killer. Convicted of  murders, hersquos the most prolic serial killer in America. His victims were mostly sex workers and runaways. He was spared the death penalty but will die in prison.JOHN DOUGLAS ON FILM AND TVSCOTT Glen famously portrayed a version of John Douglas in The Silence of the Lambs, but itrsquos the Netflix series Mindhunter which has really brought the detail of his work to le for millions.In Mindhunter, the lead character Holden Ford is based on Douglasrsquo early career with the FBIrsquos Behavioural Science Unit. Douglas along with his colleague Robert Ressler - the man who coined the term serial killer - began travelling the country interviewing serial offenders in prison to gain insight into how they think in the hope of using the information to catch offenders still at large.Their work would have been impossible without Dr Ann Burgess who was studying ways to help women who had been raped. Her work looking at crime from the victimrsquos perspective helped develop a  degree view of serial crime. The three eventually published the Crime Classication Manual, which remains a handbook for detectives today.Douglas has also been played by Hugh Dancy as special investigator Will Graham in the series Hannibal, which charts the le of the fictional serial killer Hannibal Lecter.Douglas is now retired from the FBI but continues to consult on major crime. He worked on the Amanda Knox case, and supported her claim of innocence, and also helped free a number of men wrongfully convicted of three child murders spuriously connected to Satanism.

title: interview-scotland-secretary-david-mundell-on-independence-brexit-and-david-cameron
story: David Cameronrsquos coalition beefed up Holyroodrsquos tax-ying abilities after implementing the recommendations of the Calman commission.A majority Conservative Government then accepted the post-indyref Smith Commission findings which gave the Parliament new tax and social security powers.The Tory politician who was involved with both sets of reforms was David Mundell, who in a twenty-year career in politics has served at Holyrood and Westminster.He was a junior Minister in the Scotland Office for the Calman legislation, and was Cameronrsquos Secretary of State of Scotland when the Smith proposals were turned into law. He has been in the same post for nearly four years and is in Prime Minister Theresa Mays Cabinet.: SNP members support new currency as soon as practicableSitting in his office in the west end of Edinburgh - two pillows nestle on the sofa, one with a saltire and the other emblazoned with a Union Jack - the MP for Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale  Tweeddale is keen to mention his role in post-devolution politics.However, achievements of the past cannot mask problems of the present. Mundell is at the centre of two constitutional storms that show little sign of settling down.We met twenty four hours after First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced plans for another independence referendum, a policy he vigorously opposes.He is also the Scottish Tory face of Mayrsquos troubled Brexit deal, which has been rejected by MPs on three occasions. Brexit has been delayed and voters will have the opportunity to vote in the European elections next month. The Tories are expecting a drubbing.ldquoItrsquos inevitable now, Mundell says of the elections, wearily. ldquoWersquove run out of time. The reason we are having it is one of the reasons I think many people voted to leave the EU, in the sense that lsquorules are rulesrsquo.Askedhe expected the election would be dficult for his party, he replies: ldquoAll the evidence would suggest that it is going to be a challenge, but wersquove had challenges before.The Governmentrsquos focus is on producing an alternative set of proposals that could command the support of MPs. With Tory right wingers opposed to Mayrsquos deal, the Prime Minister has turned to Labour, who are demanding a customs union.Mundell has previously said the Government would be ldquowilling to discuss such a proposal. However, would he be willing to discuss having a confirmatory vote, which would pit Mayrsquos deal against Remain in another referendum ldquoThe Government doesnrsquot support a confirmatory vote. I donrsquot support a confirmatory vote. Wersquove had two attempts to bring that forward in the House of Commons, he says.ldquoMy personal view is that there is not a majority of MPs in the House of Commons for a confirmatory vote. I donrsquot think there is a logic to it.Mundell campaigned for Remain in  and is known to have a disregard for some of his more bloody-minded Brexiteer colleagues.I have three shots at asking him how he would vote in the event of a second referendum,the choice was between Mayrsquos plan and Remain.ldquoI want to respect the outcome of the referendum wersquove had, so I donrsquot want there to be another referendum, he says. That was a dodge.I press again. Would he back Mayrsquos deal in another referendum  ldquoIrsquom not trying to evade the question. Irsquom clear that her deal is the best deal that is on offer for us to leave the EU. Irsquom clear that we need to respect the outcome of the initial referendum.I ask a dferent version of the same question. Is it possible you could vote Remain ldquoNo, ldquo he says firmly. ldquoI would find it dficult to vote Remain in a future referendum because it would not be respecting the outcome of the previous referendum.Picture of David Mundell by Gordon TerrisI read him recent comments by Scottish Tory MP Stephen Kerr, who said that Tory hardliners displayed the same sort of ldquoromanticised and ldquosometimes xenophobic attitudes as some Scottish nationalists.Mundell appears to concur with his colleaguersquos assessment. ldquoThere are a group of Conservative colleagues whose entire political approach is driven by Brexit, he says.ldquoThey are as obsessive about Brexit as Nicola Sturgeon and some of her colleagues are about independence. Brexit matters to them more than any of the circumstances around it, or other things that are happening.Paul Hutcheon: Nicola Sturgeons route to indyref is through Jeremy CorbynGeorge Osborne, the former Tory chancellor, was revealed recently to have argued against holding an EU referendum before it became Government policy.I ask Mundell, who has always had a pragmatic view on the EU,he was also privately sceptical at that time.ldquoI felt that we had committed to doing it and I felt there wasnrsquot any way of not doing it, having committed to doing it, he says, cryptically.Mundell believes the problem was in the EU reform package Cameron negotiated with European partners ahead of the referendum.If the EU had given more ground, particularly on freedom of movement, Mundell believes this could have shted the dial.ldquoIf David Cameron had been able to secure a dferent package, a better package...that might have ended up dferently.Mundell was an early supporter of Cameron. He backed his leadership bid in  and warmed to his social liberalism. However, Cameronrsquos stock has plummeted after becoming the unwitting architect of a policy - Brexit - he never wanted.He says he has ldquono regrets about voting for Cameron, but concedes the former Prime Minister may have a problem with his legacy.ldquoAs at this moment, he is defined by that referendum and the result, he says.ldquoIn ten years time, we will be able to make that judgement, as to whether that is entirely the dominant feature, in the way that the Iraq war has become Tony Blairrsquos legacy.ldquoWhether we see David Cameron solely in that context or not, I donrsquot know. I hope not.Tory MSPs are becoming increasingly restless about the Brexit farce. Their party made impressive gains at the last general election and are focused on trying to win the Holyrood poll in . Does Mundell believe Brexit is harming Ruth Davidsonrsquos chances of becoming First Minister ldquoI donrsquot think it is, because Ruth will very clearly in the  election set out to people what the clear choice in that election is, which is Nicola Sturgeon continuing as First Minister, independence and a threat of a referendum never going away, compared to Ruthrsquos offer, he says.Mundell is also taking an interest in who will succeed May, given that she wonrsquot contest the next general election:He wants the next Tory leader to have a strong commitment to the Union and be socially liberal: ldquoI want somebody who has a modern outlook and who is in touch with modern le, and how people live their lives.Boris Johnson, who has caused major problems for May, will not be his choice. Mundell has already ruled out serving in a Johnson Cabinet and aims a few more darts in his direction:ldquoI donrsquot think that he is someone who does particularly gel in Scotland.Mundell says Johnson has not had many dealings with Scotland, other than an ldquoill-fated tilt at becoming Edinburgh Universityrsquos rector:ldquoHe has not dipped his toe signicantly into the Scottish political scene. He is not necessarily somebody who has an obvious affinity with Scotland.Mundellrsquos analysis on the attributes of the next leader may be persuasive, but his comments on social liberalism niggle.In the very early days of the Scottish Parliament, when Mundell was a Tory MSP, his party launched a nasty campaign opposing the repeal of anti-gay legislation relating to schools.: SNP councillor snubbed as candidate after being quizzed on Salmond-Sturgeon rtMundell, who later came out as gay, voted against the repeal of what was then called Section . Does he regret how he voted ldquoIt was a point in time. To me, now, it does very much look like history, the way in which that unfolded, he says.Can he see why the LGBT community would be bitter about this episode ldquoI can understand why people can turn their focus backward, but I think itrsquos better to think of actually what has been achieved in that period. What has been achieved in that period of twenty years has [been] a wholesale change in attitude, here in Scotland and across the UK, he replies.Back to the day job, his Cabinet colleague David Liddington last week ruled out a second independence referendum - by way of sanctioning a Section  order - before .Mundell goes further. Askedhe could ever imagine a Tory Government agreeing a section  order, he says:ldquoNo, I canrsquot envisage that circumstance.He then softens slightly: ldquoWersquove had a referendum. It was to be a once-in-a-generation event. Now we could have a debate about how long a generation is, but not in the forseeable future.His view is a minority Labour Government, led by Corbyn, is the biggest threat to the Union.ldquoCorbyn is Nicolarsquos route to a referendum. Itrsquos the only route to a referendum.Mundell, as the longest-serving Scottish Secretary since Ian Lang in the s, is a canny political operator who has helped add to the powers of the Parliament. Whether his legacy survives the winds of Brexit and independence remains to be seen.BIOGRAPHY - : Tory MSP for South of Scotland - present day: Tory MP for Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale - : Shadow Secretary of State for Scotland - : Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Scotland - present day: Secretary of State for Scotland

title: 50-years-since-the-open-university-transformed-learning
story: MAN had just set foot on the moon and planet earth suddenly felt a little smaller.It was , the time of Woodstock, the end of The Beatles and the launch of the Raleigh Chopper. In homes across the land, black and white television sets flickered with images of Patrick Troughton as Dr Who and for the lucky few with a colour set, there was the first chance to see Coronation Street ndash and Elsie Tannerrsquos red hair - in glorious colour.The box in the corner was already sucking up more and more of our time. And for those with a thirst for knowledge, for whom university had seemed like something for other people from posher homes to do, it was about to become a passport to a whole new world.Of course for many, the Open University - which this week marked  years since it was handed its charter to help distance learners achieve their dreams - will always be associated with late night BBC programmes presented by hirsute, softly-spoken chaps who looked like they spent evenings in a bedsit listening to Yes, pondering Cantors Theorem over a bottle of brown ale.But for more than two million students, including those who diligently set video recorders, stayed up late or rose early to catch a man in corduroy explaining Einstein and the Laws of Nature using a cardboard train and a clock, it was le-changing.Founded in  by Harold Wilsons Labour government and driven forward by Fe-born Minister for the Arts, Jenny Lee, the so-called lsquoUniversity of the Airrsquo may have been frowned upon by the establishment at birth, but today is playing a key role in educating the nation, helping to fill skills gaps and delivering to Scotlandrsquos employers ndash from the NHS to Fintech start-ups - university-level students with real le and work skills.And, of course, at  years old with modern digital technology at its fingertips, todayrsquos long-distance OU lectures are a much more modern learning experience.ldquoIt has changed a lot of peoplersquos lives who would not have had the chance in the first place, either because of economic circumstances, because they didnrsquot have the chance at school or didnrsquot just didnrsquot really like school, says Marie Hendry, Depute Director for External Engagement and Partnership for the OU in Scotland. ldquoIt has helped peoplersquos lives have changed for the better.Those old grainy black and white programmes and handful of courses long ago have now given way to highly-sophisticated digital-based distance learning. There are now over  modules offered by OU in Scotland,  associate lecturers, and online lectures which make use of foreign-language chatbots, virtual reality and articial intelligence.Since the first OU courses became available, there have been , OU qualications awarded to students in Scotland.Far from a lsquosecond chance universityrsquo for the middle-aged seeking the degree they always craved, it now attracts an increasing number of younger students ndash the median age for an OU student in Scotland is now just .Among its learners are sixth-year pupils at school ndash some in rural locations with limited access to modern languages or science teachers ndash graduate apprentices, and NHS workers looking to boost their career prospects.An increasing number of students are choosing OU over bricks and mortar rivals ndash drawn by the chance to earn and learn ndash some looking to reskill to change career, while at the other end of the scale are students in their nineties.Three-quarters of Scottish students combine studies with work, many also juggle family and carersrsquo obligations, or debilitating health problems. And the majority are ploughing through STEM subjects ndash particularly welcome for employers fearing a skills gap ndash with % of Scottish students following a STEM-related course, % of them women.ldquoThere is no typical OU student, adds Hendry. ldquoEveryone is dferent. People donrsquot come to our university. We take it to them.While debate often rages over how lsquobricks and mortarrsquo universities can shed their elitist gown and become more open to students from less wealthy backgrounds and inclusive, Hendry points out that % of OU in Scotland students come from the countryrsquos most deprived areas, and % declare a disability - % of which are mental health related.In Logan close to Cumnock, mother of three Leeanne MacPherson, , is managing her BAMental Health Nursing degree alongside night shts, school runs and day to day le. ldquoYou donrsquot even want to see the ironing, she laughs.But the opportunity to study for her nursing degree while continuing to work as a nursing assistant an NHS Ayrshire and Arran mental health unit for the elderly in East Ayrshire has, she says, been le-changing. ldquoItrsquos been the best opportunity I have ever had, she says.Collaborative working between OU in Scotland, the Scottish Government and NHS boards has opened the door to nursing staff like her wanting to advance their qualications without stopping work ndash meaning they can continue to fill vital health roles as they train.For Leeanne, itrsquos a chance to gain the nursing qualication she once thought may have passed her by after leaving school, working in a jeans factory and then combining raising her family with working in childcare and then in mental health.ldquoI do feel guilty sometimes when Irsquom sitting with the laptop and the kids are saying theyrsquore bored and want to do something, she admits. ldquoThere can be sacrices, but itrsquos four years to get me where I want to be. ldquoIn Inverness, Karis Williamson, who has congenital muscular dystrophy, also says the OU has been le-changing. ldquoIt has given me some self-respect, and re-educated me about what education really is and who I really am and what Im capable of, she says.Karis, who features as part of a new photography collection taken by renowned British photographer Chris Floyd, to mark the OUrsquos th Anniversary, began studying with OU aged , mostly ploughing her way through Arts modules.She is now studying for a BA Open Degree, which allows students to choose their own subjects to build a bespoke qualication. Support through the university and the Disabled Studentsrsquo Allowancehas given her access to invaluable equipment, including an eye-gaze computer and special software.Most of her studying is done at home in Inverness, where her garden shed has been turned into a lsquoBook Templersquo. ldquoDue to my illness I can never take tomorrow for granted, she says. ldquoI wanted to squash in as much as possible while I can.Perhaps once considered a lesser option than a traditional degree, Hendry - who is herself studying for an OU MBA - believes employers are increasingly recognising the quality of an OU graduate.ldquoThey say time and again that the people who graduate have effective time management skills and that tenacity to be able to study at the same time as manage careers and family and other responsibilities. Theyrsquore adaptable, flexible and creative thinkers.It makes for an emotional graduation ceremony, she adds.ldquoThere are people who are recovering from cancer, or whose parents have died while they were studying, they might have health issues or worked hard around a family.ldquoThere are tears. They are often crying, and we are often crying with them.ldquoItrsquos lovely.Tie pieceThe Open University has attracted well-known figures keen to improve their knowledge, and had an impact on television viewersrsquo and radio listenersrsquo understanding of culture, nature and science.Sir Lenny Henry, who presented an hour-long BBC documentary Happy Birthday OU:  Years of the Open University, on Thursdayobtained an English Literature BAin .He said: ldquoWithout the OU I would never have dreamt of making all the documentaries I have done in the last  years. Because of the OU, I have been able to engage with these texts in a critical fashion with some academic polish.Other well-known former students include Myleene Klass , Holly Willoughby , Jerry Halland serial killer Myra Hindley .Meanwhile, retired newsreader Anna Fordrsquos first television work was as a social studies tutor for the OU from -. And Robin Wilson, the son of Prime Minister Harold Wilson who was a major driving force behind its creation, went on to be an OU maths professor.The OU also gave some famous names their first television break ndash David Tennant and Daniel Craig were in OU televised dramas. David Prowse ndash the actor who filled the imposing shoes of Darth Vader in Star Wars ndash also appeared in the OUrsquos version of Jean Genetrsquos The Balcony.Each year the OU co-produces approximately  prime-time TV and radio series. They have included some of the UKrsquos best-loved programmes including Coast, James Mayrsquos Big Ideas, Bang Goes the Theory and Blue Planet II.Radio commissions have included Economics with Subtitles, BBC Inside Science and The Bottom Line.The OU has also played a role in fiction. The Archers, Brookside, Ever Decreasing Circles, Birds of a Feather and Goodnight Sweetheart have all had OU students written into their plots, while actress Julie Waltersrsquo big film break came when she portrayed an OU student opposite Michael Caine in Educating Rita.Minister for further and higher education, Richard Lochhead, said: ldquoAs one of the worldrsquos first successful distance teaching universities, the Open University was founded on the belief that communications technology could bring high quality degree-level learning to people who had not had the opportunity to attend traditional campus universities. More than  million people from over  countries have benefited from their courses.ldquoI congratulate the Open University on its th anniversary and commend it for its long tradition of widening access to higher education for learners from non-traditional backgrounds, and for its approach to flexible learning, giving every student the opportunity to learn in a way that benefits them.

title: kelvingrove-animals-are-deep-frozen-to-eliminate-moths
story: This alarming process is happening right now in a wardrobe near you ndash and disturbingly, Tineola bisselliellaseems to be growing ever more rampant. According to The Heraldrsquos fashion editor Eva Arrighi, the pests ndash which appear partial to fine silk, angora and cashmere ndash are creating intense fear and loathing within the rag trade. Former Vogue editor Alexandra Shulman famously declared war on the tiny creatures ndash they are only half-an-inch across ndash after her designer wardrobe was attacked and Arrighi now fears for her own vintage coat collection after discovering that the blighters had been silently chomping through the carpets beneath her household furniture.Insecticide sales are soaring and itrsquos not only domestic properties that are at risk. Earlier this month it was reported that carpets in the High Court of Glasgow had been treated for moth infestation.Meanwhile, stately homes are on high alert. At Newhailes house, Musselburgh, the biggest moth control programme ever mounted by the National Trust for Scotlandis under way after a sharp increase in insect activity was detected there. As NTS preventive conservator Mel Houston explains, the exercise is designed to nip the problem in the bud before the moth population explodes.: Hundreds of climate change activists pretend to die in Glasgow museumShe attributes the insectsrsquo UK-wide expansion to central heating, the popularity of luxury fabrics and perhaps lower housekeeping standards than our forebears, and the Newhailes anti-moth programme includes lots of ldquovery unglamorous cleaning, cleaning and more cleaning. ldquoMoths donrsquot like being disturbed, explains Houston, ldquoandyou keep hoovering, you hoover up the eggs and larvae and reduce the population.The NTS has also created a mini-ice age within the th-century country house by installing two huge freezers cold enough to kill adult insects, larvae and eggs. Priceless historic carpets, curtains and even sofas are being systematically removed from their settings, wrapped and then chilled to minus-C before being ed to the deep-cleaned rooms, which will then be carefully monitored to guard against re-infestation.Glasgow Museums, which owns textiles and costumes dating back to the year , also adopts the freezer method: the Burrellrsquos entire tapestry collection has been put through the servicersquos own industrial-sized chiller as a precaution. And as preventive conservator David Thomson points out, this isnrsquot a new technique. ldquoIn the old days, anyone with fur coats would take them to the furrier to be kept in cold storage during the warm summer months.Clothes moths have been around for a long time ndash though no-one seems sure whether they are native to these shores or were imported from warmer climes, perhaps on the tunic of a Roman soldier or even a Bronze Age warrior. We do know that they are an age-old nuisance. In , Elizabeth I engaged eight men to spend a full day beating Windsor Castlersquos furs to rid them of moths. But in modern times, says Thomson, the problem became considerably more troublesome around  years ago ndash perhaps, he speculates, following the ban on naphthalene-based insecticides such as mothballs.This isnrsquot just a UK problem. In some American museums, where millions of dollars are spent on pest control, people are banned from bringing overcoats into buildings. Could museums of the future institute a polyester clothing rule, I wonder.The recent ldquodramatic increase in moth numbers means Thomson now devotes much of his working le to the threat and, like Houston, he says scrupulous cleaning is crucial.ldquoDust, which is largely skin particles and clothing fibres, accumulates , times faster in a museum context because of the large number of people in our buildings, he points out.ldquoSo we need to make sure our housekeeping is based on good old hoovering, and that display systems donrsquot create dust traps.ldquoWe are refurbishing the Burrell and itrsquos really important that our redisplays of the tapestries are safe from infestation. One of the ways wersquore doing that is trying to ensure our buildings are scrupulously cleanable, and some of the design work for the new Burrell is based around eliminating the possibility of dust traps.: Hundreds of climate change activists pretend to die in Glasgow museumStored objects are regularly checked, quarantined and treated as necessary and as Thomson points out, taxidermy is particularly vulnerable. Moth larvae live on keratin, the protein which makes up skin, hair, nails and feathers. Every so often, says Thomson, one of Kelvingroversquos much-loved stuffed birds or mammals has to be removed from display and placed in the freezer. ldquoThe natural history conservator knows how to look for tell-tale signs, he adds. ldquoMost obviously, they might spot an adult moth exiting from its feathers. That means it has pupated there. If you look closely you can sometimes see the larvae or its faeces, which is called frass.In domestic settings, the signs are similar. ldquoThe most obvious one is flying adult moths, says Thomson. ldquoIf eggs have been laid on your favourite jumper, you wonrsquot see them because they are too small for the human eye butyou notice holes and look closer, you may see caterpillars which have hatched out and increased in size after eating [your jumper]. Theyrsquore white with a brown head.Icky as all this sounds, Thomson freely admits to having moths in his own home ndash which like most old tenements has plenty of the floorboard and skirting gaps that can harbour the insects. In fact, he seems almost grateful for these domestic close encounters, for helping him get to know his professional enemy.Back at Newhailes, Mel Houston says she and her colleagues are deliberately ldquoopen about washing our dirty linen in public, because we are doing the best we can and we know that a lot of our visitors have moth problems themselves. In fact, wersquove been running tours to let people see how we are cleaning, how we are treating the problem and looking after our properties and collections.A keen environmentalist who is also a member of the Bugle conservation trust, Houston is conscious of the apparent irony of targeting the insects at a time when many moth species are under threat. Just last week, Scottish Natural Heritagereported that moth numbers have declined by % over the past  years, with moorland species particularly affected ndash a trend attributed to global warming, and changes in land management and habitats.Clothes moths, however, were not covered in the report and SNH trends and indicators analyst Simon Foster is heartened that the NTS is raising awareness of the many ieties of valuable moths and butterflies. Moths, he says, are ldquomuch maligned because of one or two troublesome species and while he understands the need to control the clothes-munching iety, he points out that overall, moths are ldquoa really important group for pollinating plants and ldquoa key part of Scotlandrsquos natural environment.A glimpse of a flitting Burnet or Cinnabar should convince anyone that these beautul creatures are welcome within our midst. Nor is the clothes moth itself an unlovely specimen, with its delicate wings and fluttering flight pattern. Its offspring, however, are destructive and while banishing them from our homes completely seems unlikely , spring is a good time to try. ldquoIf you can prevent them mating and laying eggs, yoursquove reduced the cycle, says David Thomson.Fashion editor Eva Arrighi is also on the case. Having spent ldquoa fortune on moth-killing treatments, she now conducts nightly patrols of her home, waiting for a winged invader to flit into her path. ldquoMy kids think Irsquove gone mad and Irsquom prone to agree, she says. ldquoBut I think you have to be obsessive to deal with moths.Moth-busting tipsMoths, says Mel Houston, are "secretive" beasties, which hide themselves away and only emerge to look for a mate or a suitable woolly birthing place. By the time you see them, theyve already done their worst since its the larvae that munch through your clothes and carpets before emerging as adult moths.To prevent further damage:Hoover frequently, particularly under furniture .Use pheromone traps to monitor moth activity in your home.Wash clothes before storing and ideally place in sealed plastic bags.Our fashion editor Eva Arrighi recommends placing lavender bags or cedar balls in clothes drawers, though she suggests the latter should be sanded to release the aroma.If infestation is suspected, wash garments at the highest temperature the fabric will stand.For woollens and delicates, borrow a tip from our conservation experts by wrapping in plastic bags and placing in your freezer for a week or two to kill moths, eggs and larvae.Chemical moth-killers are effective when used according to manufacturers instructions. For serious infestations, consider engaging the services of a professional pest-control company, which will be licensed to use fumigation techniques.

title: ready-steady-fundraise-the-london-marathon-revolution
story: Last year it hauled in a whopping pound. million and that record is set to be blown yet again, with at least a fth more donations pledged for this year. Those who run it are, in some ways, participants in two marathons ndash one a . mile pounding of road and pavement, the other an ultrathon of pledge-gathering. Admirable as their mile-clocking may be, still more impressive are their fundraising powers of endurance.For charities, the Virgin Money London Marathon can be a crucial leline ndash and ballots are prized and envied. Meanwhile, becoming the marathons partner is like hitting the jackpot. This year the recipient of this blessing has been the attention-grabbing Dementia Revolution, which represents the combined forces Alzheimerrsquos Society and Alzheimer Research UK. Dame Barbara Windsor is its unofficial figurehead ndash not only the inspiration for Barbararsquos Revolutionaries, a running team pulled together by her husband, Scott Mitchell, but also for many others across the nation.Behind every pound raised by runners is some sort of personal tale, often involving a loved one lost to a disease, or struggling with a condition. Among these, for instance, is -year-old Kath Murray, who has been inspired to run by the fact that her mother has recently been diagnosed with dementia. She is fundraising not for Dementia Revolution but for its Scottish cousin, Alzheimer Scotland.Murray is one of the % of the UK applications for this yearrsquos run who have never run a marathon before. Before she signed up for this yearrsquos event, she considered, she says, she ldquocould not run. ldquoI was not a runner, she recalls, ldquoIn my school days, I remember, I used to duck out of the running activities. I used to say, lsquoI canrsquot run.rsquo It baffled my teachers. A year ago I was interested to join a Jog Scotland group, and went to their running sessions for a few weeks, but I didnrsquot really stick at it.ldquoI just got a bee in my bonnet," she says, "about trying to give the London Marathon a go this year. I felt more driven because of what happened with my mum. Irsquom not naturally a runner, so itrsquos been a bit of a mad thing for me to sign up to do this. With Alzheimer Scotland providing support to my family I decided obviously I should apply to get one of their spaces.Her mother, who is , was recently diagnosed as having early onset dementia. Murray says that her mum is ldquoin denial about her condition. Though they talk about her running and the fact that she is fundraising for Alzheimer Scotland, she is not aware that her daughter doing it ldquofor her. ldquoA couple of times Irsquove been down to visit her, she says, ldquoand had to do my training run while Irsquom there, but we donrsquot talk about it as relating to her. My mum is keeping the two things separate. Shersquos not really clocked that itrsquos all about her ndash and Irsquove not made a point of pointing it out to her. She just thinks Irsquom a bit mad.During training she used the -week plan advised in the book, The Non Runnerrsquos Marathon Trainer. ldquoOnce Alzheimer Scotland offered me the place, she says, ldquowhich was last October, I realised Irsquoll need to start getting myself in gear ndash so I signed up and did a K Santa run at the start of December. That was really my very first training runyou like. For me it was a real struggle. I was pretty much the last in the group of people to finish. To begin with I had to do quite a bit of walking in between running. Itrsquos been quite scary looking back the miles that Irsquove done since starting back in January to doing short three mile training runs to recently my longest runs at  miles.Of the thousands of runners who take to the route ndash there were over , last year ndash many are Scots. The causes they run for are wide-ranging. Some, like -year-old Gillian McDonald, who is raising money for the Fragile X Society, are running for small charities with relatively tiny profiles ndash causes that struggle to stand out from the rest of the pack. McDonald observes: ldquoYou go to these events and there are charities which have hundreds and hundreds of runners, running for them. And I felt I was like there on my own. Itrsquos something you feel is a bit unfair that they get all these charity places and there are other charities that are desperate for the profile and the funds.Steven Henderson, Aberdeen, Running for Scottish Huntingtonrsquos Association"Itrsquos my third London Marathon in a row. I did my first in . Huntingtonrsquos disease has been in my family for a while. Itrsquos hereditary and has gone back through my grandfatherrsquos side of the family. It has affected my mother, my sister. Irsquove not actually been tested for it ndash so I donrsquot knowI have got it or not. Irsquove got a : chance. I decided I didnrsquot want to be tested for it yet.My mum started to get symptoms when she was in her thirties. Shersquos just coming up for sixty and itrsquos now got quite a hold. It has affected her mobility, her speech. One of the most noticeable things is the fact that my mum fidgets quite a lot. Overall it takes away the ability to do anything ndash her speech, her hearing, her memory, her walking. If you knew my mum ten years ago, you would hardly recognise her from then.Itrsquos something thatrsquos very close to me, soit were possible to find a cure, or anything to help, all the better.I actually took up running for a bit of a laugh when an older family member said that I was putting on a bit of weight. One of my friends I played football with ran the marathon in , and I thought, Maybe Irsquoll give it a go. I got in touch with Huntingtonrsquos thinking I could do it for them.I was never a runner, by any shape or form. But Ive taken to it and I enjoy it now. It takes my mind off things like work. Irsquom a coordinator for an oil and gas services company and the job itself is quite stressful. Running is something I look forward to doing. It takes my mind off work and helps me cope. Doing the marathon itself gives me a sense of pride that through the money I generate and collect Irsquove been able to contribute towards something rather than just hoping that some progress will happen in finding a cure for Huntingtonrsquos."Andy Cunningham, Dundee, Running for Maggiersquos Centres"When I ran the London marathon for Maggiersquos Centres in , it was my first ever run in anything. I was never a runner before. I was a swimmer when I was growing up and could swim for hours, but the minute it was running, I was done.My mum had breast cancer when I was growing up and more recently she has been diagnosed with leukaemia. When I chose Maggiersquos Centre in  she didnrsquot have cancer. I chose it because Irsquom a teacher and I was doing my masters in pupil care and support. I chose to research into how schools can support pupils whose parents have cancer. I heard about Maggiersquos and got familiar with what they do and it inspired me. I like the way they help people deal with cancer, whether emotionally or by providing that space for people to understand whatrsquos going on with their lives.After the first marathon, I felt the atmosphere was just so amazing that I knew I would want to do it again. This year I decided to apply to Maggiersquos Centres again. I came up with this fund-raising idea of doing something with the mini penguins that Maggiersquos had produced following their Penguin Parade public art thing they did in Dundee last year. My we, a childrenrsquos author, Pamela Butchart, has lots of friends that are quite big childrenrsquos illustrators and it all kind of came into place, and we got some of them to paint them, so we could raffle them offBetween my first marathon and now, wersquove had a wee baby, who is now  months. First time round there was no baby and I was in the routine of following a fitness plan and got into it. This time round itrsquos been more dficult to find the time to do it with the baby ndash but itrsquos also been easier because I kind of know what I need to be doing distance-wise."Gillian McDonald, Peebles, Running for Fragile X SocietyldquoIrsquove got twin boys called Stuart and Matthew, who will be  this year. They were diagnosed with Fragile X when they were about ten years old. There are things that they find really challenging ndash like reading and writing ndash and theyrsquore quite excitable, so they do a lot of hand-clapping. I hadnrsquot heard of Fragile X till I saw something about it on the news about ten years ago. It ticked so many boxes that I then asked for the boys to be tested for it which can only be done through a blood test. There is no cure ndash so itrsquos really just coping mechanisms.As soon as we got the diagnosis of Fragile X we turned to the society ndash and my husband has since been its chair. Last year the society managed to win one place for the London marathon in the charity ballot and they then put it out to tender to the rest of the society. I had done some research and saw most charities are looking for a couple of thousand pounds, so I said I would try to raise pound. In the end I raised over pound, by doing lots of dferent events.All my focus was on the fundraising, and the running of the marathon was just something that had to happen at the end. My sons came down and they dyed their hair blue which is the colour of the society.This time I applied to the general ballot and when I got a place it was a bit of a no-brainer that I would run for the society again.Fragile X is the most common inherited learning disorder, but itrsquos quite surprising how many people havenrsquot heard of it ndash whereas everybody has heard of autism. There could be quite a lot of people who are being thought of as autistic, who could potentially have Fragile X, but theyrsquove not had the blood test.Shane Jamieson, Southampton, Running for Chest Heart And Stroke ScotlandldquoMy family have supported Chest Heart And Stroke Scotland for the past few years, following the passing of my grandfather, Harry. We ran the Berlin half marathon as a family, and I just thought Irsquod like to take up the challenge of a marathon.Irsquom originally from Shetland and my grandfather, who owned a shop there, was always quite full of le. A few years ago he went in for an operation in Aberdeen and unfortunately during his recovery had a stroke and passed away from that. The support we received from CHSS is the reason why wersquore raising for them. My grandfather was just over  and had this kind of attitude that he was probably going to live for ever. It came as quite a shock when he passed.Obviously everyone has their own story of why they do the marathon. For me, the charitable cause is the reason you get out of bed ndash because yoursquore doing it for a reason and a good cause. But at the runs themselves you are looking just to get through and put one foot in front of the other.

title: scottish-labour-mp-corbyn-brexit-leaflet-is-bulls
story: Leaked WhatsApp messages show Paul Sweeney describing the leaflet as ldquobull****, while colleagues Ged Killen and Martin Whitfield both blasted it as a ldquodisaster.Whitfield added that ldquowe need a rethink or Labour will be dead in Scotland, while Killen claimed that the ldquoparty is in crisis in Scotland.In the same exchange, Edinburgh South MP Ian Murray said he was getting dozens of emails from constituents saying they are no longer voting Labour.Paul Hutcheon: Nicola Sturgeons route to indyref is through Jeremy CorbynCorbyn and his allies support a soft version of Brexit, but many of the partyrsquos MPs and members are staunchly pro-Remain and want to stay in the European Union by way of another referendum.Opposition to Corbynrsquos stance is evident in Scotland, where over % of voters backed Remain in . Many senior figures in Scottish Labour want him to adopt a robust anti-Brexit stance.Tensions flared up again last week over Labourrsquos draft leaflet for the upcoming European elections.Remainers were outraged after one version appeared to show Labour backing an EU exit and not mentioning a second referendum. MEP candidates and parliamentarians across the UK were not said to have been consulted on the contents.After one of the leaflets was posted in a WhatsApp group that includes Scottish Labour MPs, Sweeney, who is Corbynrsquos Shadow Minister for Scotland, wrote:ldquoIf itrsquos like this then itrsquos a bad misjudgement and Irsquom having nothing to do with it.The Glasgow North East MP, who supports a second referendum, added: ldquoLetrsquos hope the NEC [Labourrsquos governing body] kill this bulls*** line.: SNP members support new currency as soon as practicableMurray, a staunch critic of Corbyn, informed the same group:ldquoI canrsquot believe the party are going to put a leaflet out to every household in my constituency and we havenrsquot even been given the common courtesy of seeing it. We are not allowed to spend anything ourselves so we are just to suck this up and watch our support fall off a clf.He added: ldquoI think Irsquoll start posting the dozens of emails Irsquom getting every day from constituents who are no longer voting labour .ldquoGiven there are only  MPs and  sitting MEP it wouldnrsquot have taken any time at all to have consulted on the content.Sweeney added: ldquoWould be better off putting nothing out. I would only use that as targeted mail to IDrsquod Leave voters.Killen, who represents Rutherglen and Hamilton West, wrote: ldquoI agree, the leaflet is a disaster and I canrsquot endorse it. The party is in crisis in Scotland and I think we need an urgent plan to address this.He added: ldquoSNP were on the way out this time two years ago and we have given them a new lease of le.:Second Scottish Labour figure linked to charity embroiled in harassment scandalMartin Whitfield, the MP for East Lothian, wrote: ldquoAgree with Paul Ged and Ian. The leaflet is a disaster and the polling [there was bad polling for Labour yesterday] is yet more of a wake up call.He continued: ldquoWe need a rethink or labour will be dead in Scotland. Real possibility that we could have no elected reps outside of Scottish parliament.It is also understood there is disquiet about Corbynrsquos face being on the draft leaflet for Scotland, rather than Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard.A source said Corbynrsquos office had resisted attempts at changing the draft. The NEC is set to make a final decision this week.A Scottish Labour spokesperson declined to comment.

title: snp-members-support-new-currency-as-soon-as-practicable
story: In what will likely be the key flashpoint in any second referendum, the party supported the preparation of a Scottish currency ldquoas soon as practicable.Sturgeonrsquos allies had opposed this amendment at her partyrsquos conference in Edinburgh yesterday, but the proposal was pushed through after a tight vote.Sturgeon last week backed another independence referendum within two years, a policy ruled out by the Tory Government.Iain Macwhirter: Nicola Sturgeon is storing up trouble by talking about an early referendum she cant deliverAt the SNP spring conference in Edinburgh yesterday, the Nationalists debated reforms to a post-independence economic policy that many in the Yes movement believe is out of date.The  referendum was dominated by the SNP Governmentrsquos plan for a post-independence currency union with the rest of the UK .It would have resulted in Scotland sharing the pound and the infrastructure of the Bank of England with the rUK, but Labour, the LibDems and the Tories ruled out the plan.Senior Yes campaigners believed the currency issue was a turn-off for voters and the main reason for their defeat.Nicola Sturgeon, who succeeded Alex Salmond as SNP leader and First Minister, then set up the Growth Commission to rethink her partyrsquos economic prospectus.The Commission, under the chairmanship of former SNP MSP Andrew Wilson, recommended that an independent Scotland should keep the pound in an extended transition period.However, left-wingers in the Yes movement believed the Commissionrsquos stance, which they dubbed "sterlingisation", amounted to the SNP ceding control of monetary policy to the rUk.Interview: Scotland Secretary David Mundell on independence, Brexit and David CameronIn Edinburgh yesterday, SNP depute leader Keith Brown and Scottish Government Finance Secretary Derek Mackay tabled a resolution which tried to address the concerns of critics by committing an SNP Government to establishing an independent currency.The resolution did not provide a timescale, but instead noted that the process would be guided by an independent Scotland meeting six economic tests set by the Commission.It added that sterling would be used until a new currency could be ldquosafely and securely established in the interests of the whole economy.The leadership headed off a rival plan to set up a new currency within the first term of an independent Parliament, but Sturgeon suffered a reverse over another amendment which appeared to bring more urgency to ditching the pound:ldquoConference considers that an SNP Government should take the steps necessary to enable the Scottish Parliament to authorise the preparation of a Scottish currency as soon as practicable after a vote for independence with the aim that the currency be ready for introduction as soon as practicable after Independence Day.Even though this amendment passed, the six tests laid down in the original motion remain in place.George Kerevan, a former SNP MP, was one of the most senior Nationalists to speak in favour of a new currency being set up in the first term of an independent Scotland.He described the main resolution as ldquovague and said of the prospect of selling a policy of a new currency to voters without a timescale: ldquoTheyrsquoll not be convinced.He also told delegates: ldquoYou will have to tell them when.Kerevan added that there is a ldquomajor time bomb in the sterlingisation plan, arguing that there was ldquono way of creating reserves to bail out banks that were in trouble.Paul Hutcheon: Nicola Sturgeons route to indyref is through Jeremy CorbynAfter the vote, Kerevan told The Herald on Sunday: ldquoI am pleased the membership has forced the leadership to accept for the first time that we will introduce a new currency as soon as practicable after independence. In the meantime, I think sterlingisation will start to unravel as a policy as soon as it is put under public scrutiny.Pamela Nash, chief executive of the pro-UK Scotland in Union campaign group, said: ldquoThe SNP has voted to fast-track its plan to scrap the pound and put salaries, mortgages and pensions at risk.ldquoIn a huge challenge to Nicola Sturgeonrsquos authority, members have snubbed her proposal and voted to complete this reckless act even sooner than she wanted.Jackson Carlaw, interim leader of the Scottish Tories, said: ldquoThis is a profoundly embarrassing snub for the SNP leadership. And it shows that Nicola Sturgeon is now at the beck and call of an extreme economic agenda within the SNP which would rip the pound from our pockets as soon as possible.ldquoIt only underlines the growing need to stand up against Nicola Sturgeon and say no to a second referendum so we can focus on what matters, not the SNPrsquos deeply dangerous plans to dump the pound.Two polls published last week showed that the public are opposed to the pound being scrapped in favour of a new currency.A Survation poll, commissioned by Scotland in Union, found that % of respondents wanted to continue with the pound. Around % backed a separate currency.Fewer than one in of the , adults polled said they wanted to use the euro instead of the pound.A YouGov poll published by a daily newspaper yesterday also found little support for the plan to gradually introduce a new currency after independence.The survey found that % of those polled backed the proposal, while % were in favour of the euro. Only % of voters expressed a preference for a new currency straight after independence.However, other poll data by the same company was more encouraging for supporters of independence with % of respondents backing independence, up from % in YouGovrsquos last poll for the same newspaper in June.Meanwhile, Sturgeon will use her keynote speech tomorrow to attack the Conservatives for opposing indyref.She is expected to say: ldquoThe UK Government says it will block Scotlandrsquos right to choose.ldquoA right to choose mandated in not just one but two Scottish elections. And endorsed by the Scottish Parliament.She will also say: ldquoOn Thursday, they tried to justy their position by saying there was no upsurge in support for independence. Two days later the latest opinion poll was already proving them wrong. It shows support for independence already up.Sturgeon will also announce plans that could see greater regulation of short-term let firms such as Airbnb: ldquoWe are asking for views on a new system of regulation to make short term lets subject to the same controls as any other accommodation.ldquoWe want to give councils the power to control the number of lets and ensure they make a contribution to the services they use.

title: lyons-and-daniels-inside-a-very-scottish-gang-feud
story: But a barely-suppressed chuckle went round the High Court when the first target of the latest explosion of violence, Robert Daniel, was asked whether there was any ill feeling between the two families. ldquoNot that I know of, he replied, straight faced.His car had been rammed by another in December , he was then chased into a house in Robroyston in the city, before being twice struck on the back of the head with a hatchet or machete.A month later Thomas Bilsland suffered a fractured skull after he was set upon in Glasgows Cranhill.Three more were to follow, including the most savage on Steven "Bonzo" Daniel. Like the other victims, his car had been secretly fitted with a tracker and in May , after a high-speed car chase which started in the Milton in north Glasgow and ended in an off-ramp of the M, a relentless attack followed, as he was set upon with knives and machete, which almost severed his nose from his face and detached his top jaw from his skull. Ambulance responders at first thought he had been shot.:Six members of Glasgow Lyons crime mob jailed for murder plot against rival Daniel clanIn the trial of the six, "Bonzo" denied that the Daniels were a serious crime family, at war with the Lyons, claiming that he didnrsquot knowthey had any enemiesThe Lyons six were last week convicted in what the High Court was told was a conspiracy of murderous intent. They will be sentenced next month.The most senior was Robert "Piggy" Pickett, a graduate of the Paisley crime scene, who has been shot, served a sentence for attempted murder, another for contempt and who, again, has a blank memory when it came to anyone who might harbour a drudge against him.Players in this violent arena often have nicknames which belie their lethal nature ndash like "Gerbil", "Goofy" ndash and in this spirit the six might be called The Bonzo Dog Band, after the Seventies pop group. They acted together and they certainly dogged Bonzo. Not that they followed the message of the  album, Letrsquos Make Up and Be Friendly.THE PAISLEY PATTERNSpecky, Goofy, and Piggy might sound astheyrsquore the characters in a Disney cartoon but nothing could be further from the truth. Theyrsquore the nommes de guerres of three of the most violent and dangerous villains who ever picked up a blade or handgun.Stewart "Specky" Boydwas the leader of a drug gang in Paisleyrsquos Ferguslie Park in the late s. Robert "Piggy Pickett was a lieutenant, as was George "Goofy" Docherty. Mark Rennie, a -year-old junkie, borrowed pound from Boyd and attempted to turn this over by small-time dealing. He didnt make the repayments which quickly spiralled, so that he was owing hundreds,not thousands, of pounds.In November , Goofy, Piggy and Stewart Gillespie turned up on Renniersquos doorstep. Gillespie handed a gun to Pickett and told him, ldquoShoot the fat b*****. Piggy clicked the trigger of the shotgun but it didnt fire, so Docherty weighed in with a machete.Rennie survived,only for six months. He vandalised the cars of the two Gillespie brothers. On May , , while trying to run away he was shot in the back. The bullet pierced his lung, spleen and then heart. He died instantly. Stewart Gillespie was the gunman.Gillespie was given a -year sentence. He served  years and was later murdered in his home. Piggy and Goofy were jailed for  and seven years for the first attempt on Rennie.On release both Piggy and Goofy joined the Lyons mob. Goofy was killed after he was stabbed and repeatedly run over in a targeted attack for which no one has been convicted. Piggy awaits his sentence.GLASGOWrsquoS RANGE WARIf there is a source of the original enmity between the two crime families, the Lyons and Daniels, rather than greed and control of drug terrain, it dates back to the summer of  when a large stash of Daniels cocaine was stolen from a house in the Milton housing scheme and sold on to the Lyons. Milton was Lyons terrain and they clearly felt that the Daniels, from nearby Possil, were moving into their fiefdom.For years the Lyons had enjoyed not just immunity, but establishment approval and support. In  Eddie Snr, already well known to police, was given disused Chirnsyde School in the Milton for a "community project". Three years later, while he was using the place as the headquarters of his crime empire, he was given pound. million in public funding.For almost two decades now the bitter feud between the gangs has seen fatal and non-fatal shootings, knings, vehicle hit and run, firebomb attacks, police corruption, witness intimidation ndash and drugs, shedloads of drugs. It is a fight to the death. Literally.In early December , Lambhill in north Glasgow became the scene of what one witness described as like a clip from a gangster movie. But there were no cameras and the blood was not ketchup or Kensington Gore. On to the forecourt of Applerow Motorswalked the main "actors" wearing long black coats. They were two Danielsrsquo hitmen, Raymond Anderson and James McDonald, who liked to call themselves The Untouchables. They were holding handguns.It was over in minutes but when the smoke cleared Lyons -year-old nephew Michael was dead on the ground, his cousin Steven was badly-wounded, as was Robert Pickett, shot three times in the stomach, later losing a kidney.At the subsequent trial of the two men Pickett claimed the wrong people were in the dock. It was suggested he had been paid to say that. Whatever the truth, he was later sentenced to two years for contempt of court over the evidence. Anderson and McDonald received the longest sentences ever passed in a Scottish court,  years.What probably sparked this carnage was the drive-by shooting three weeks earlier, in Auchinairn, Bishopbriggs, of Daniels lieutenant Kevin "Gerbil" Carroll and associate Ross Sherlock. It was the second time Gerbil had been hit, the first outside his mothers home in Milton three years earlier.Carroll had a long history with the Lyons.
